50 mins: Neville rampages (OK, shuffles) down the right wing and wins a corner. Arteta hangs it up at the near post and it's punched clear. Fuller fouls Arteta. Chance to put it in again. All free-kicks this game.

51 mins: AND EVERTON SCORE AGAIN!! It's that Arteta free-kick. Arteta drifts it in gently, Anichebe runs away from Olofinjana and unmarked glances it in. That was terrible defending. Pulis will be apopleptic as he should be.

Hard to see what Stoke do to change this round now. Try and win some free kicks maybe?

54 mins: OR THEY COULD JUST SMASH ONE IN THE TOP CORNER!! STOKE SCORE!!! Olofinjana comes up with the most amazing strike from a knock down form a long throw, volleying it into the right hand corner with incredible power.

Blimey. That was a corker. All from the long throw, weakly punched by Howard, but some amazing technique on the end of it.

56 mins: Olofinjana will be feeling better. He lost Anichebe for the Everton goal. Really top strike that.
Anichebe might be in trouble here. He's looking a bit dazed after a collision.

58 mins: Anichebe's all right. Stoke gallop forward and Delpa hurls another long throw into the box. this time it misses everyone and gets to Lawrence but his shot is off target. All sorts going on in the box there. Panic. Thrills. Screams. Cartwheels. It's the Stoke way.

60 mins: Fuller puts the ball in the net after galloping on to Kitson's flick on, but it's disallowed for a push on Yobo at the last. He finished it really well there, and then went off on a 30 second celebratory parade, before finally realising it was a free kick.
It was quite funny in the end, but you have to say that was soft. Stoke should have had another.

62 mins: Everton free kick and a huge scramble under the Stoke bar, the ball just won't go in and in the end Yakubu is penalised for a foul on the keeper. that was hairy. this is a different game.

63 mins: STOKE EQUALISE!! And it's that long throw again!! Hurled in flat from absolutely miles out by Delap and it's flicked past his own keeper by Jagielka. that was poorly dealt with, but he was under huge pressure in the crowd. Crazy game, crazy second half, crazy stuff.

65 mins: It's all going off out there now. It's a total punch-up, Stoke hurling themselves forwards, the crowd totally in it. It's kind of like Gaelic football or Aussie rules. Stoke still attacking this time through Griffin on the right. Everton really under pressure here.

67 mins: Fuller wins a corner. The crowd barks and yaps and froths. The big men are up. Another crazed set of collisions in the box. Everton escape for now.

69 mins: Everton win a corner of their own, Faye heads clear and Sorensen catches Arteta's follow up. Everton haven't had the ball for 10 minutes here. They need to take a breath and keep it for a bit or Stoke are going to trample all over them.

71 mins: A few nice little passes from the men in blue but Fellaini gives it away under pressure. He hasn't seen the ball since Stoke started bossing the game. He must be feeling a little shocked.

72 mins: Odd. It's a free kick to Everton on the edge of the penalty area for a handball by Cort that happened inside the box. His linesman seems to have talked him into giving it outside the box. He gave a penalty there at first then changed his mind. Bizarre.

Free kick is cleared.

That was hopeless. It should have been a penalty.

74 mins: And now David Moyes has been sent off for complaining. And he's gone to sit in some vacant seats with the Stoke fans. The stewards won't have that.
That was one of the worst decisions of the weekend by the way. With Respect Alan Wiley got it totally wrong.

77 mins: EVERTON SCORE!! And some kind of justice is done as tiny Tim Cahill creeps in among the huge Stoke defenders and heads in an Arteta corner awarded after Lescott boots the ball into Griffin's head. That was a lovely header. Cahill is a huge player for Everton. and he's back doing his thing.

What an amazing half.

80 mins: Brilliant play by Arteta, beating his man and feeding Yakubu, who crossed for Anichebe. His volley is deflected wide by a mighty Higginbotham lunge.
Stoke are under he cosh now. Can they get some momentum back? They've had ten minutes of all-out attack and the rest just a scuffle.

81 mins: Tonge's on for Faye. Sidibe's on for Kitson. Cahill's off for Rodwell to get another chance for Everton. Phew. Big last ten coming up you feel.

82 mins: It's all going off. Arteta booked for trying to "face down" another Delap long throw by standing in his way. It's hurled in and breaks to Griffin, who volleys it against Anichebe. Was it a handball? No one relaly knows. Ball hoofed away.

84 mins: Stoke on a bit of a surge. Pulis is out in his baseball cap yelling at everyone. Delap hoofs it too long and out for a goal kick from a promising situation.
Moyes is still sitting in among the Stoke fans. Wonder if he celebrated that goal.

86 mins: Cresswell comes on for Lawrence. One of those players who turns up in the Premier League every now and then without actually ever doing anything. Now's his chance.

87 mins: Another long throw! Go on Rory!

88 mins: hurled vast distances again but the £15m man heads it away for Everton. He's learning. Cleared for another throw, though. This one is even huger and Howard comes to catch it, fighting his way through hundreds of prone bodies.

89 mins: Stoke free kick in a very dangerous position on the corner of the area fate a needless foul by Anichebe. Swung in and headed over by Yobo under pressure. Stoke corner.

90 mins: Fellaini clears under pressure but there are 5 minutes of stoppage time for Everton to endure. It's going to be a hot.

91 mins: Ball launched forward by Sorensen and cleared for another long throw. Delap hurls it in - heard this one before? - and a stray leg (it's Sonko) hacks a bouncing ball into the side netting.
It's pretty much their only tactic, but it's a decent one here.

93 mins: Yet aanother brilliant long throw, breaks to Higginbotham, whose shot is deflected wide. That could easily have sneaked in. From the corner more half-chances, thundering challenges, fly-hacks and it's eventually cleared. Anichebe off, Vaughan on.

95 mins: Final chance to launch it form an Everton offside. Hoofed by Sorensen, flicked by Sonko and it's a corner. Here comes the keeper!

95 mins: FULL TIME. Stoke's final corner is hacked away and that's it for this afternoon.
That was an extraordinary match. the first half was dire. The second half was like pantomime, with goals, dodgy decisions, bizarre tactics and a complete lack of calm, measured football.
But it was fun for the neutral in the end and three very important points for Everton.

It has to be said, Alan Wiley made one absolutely terrible decision with the penalty. And one bad one with the Fuller goal, which was probably not a foul.

Cahill made the difference for Moyes, who ended the game shaking hands with the Stoke fans in his corner of the stand.

And that's all for me from now.

Preamble: Are we about to see the most exciting grand prix ever? That's what I've just been asked by one of my colleagues in GU towers (he wasn't jesting) and the answer surely is 'let's hope so'. Yesterday's wet qualifying session at Monza was the most shocking of the season – especially for the championship leader – and the grid is unlike any we have seen in recent years. Formula one's youngest-ever pole-sitter, Sebastian Vettel, did something with a Toro Rosso that Lewis Hamilton and Kimi Raikkonen were unable to do in their superior McLaren and Ferrari machines. It's a dream come true for the tiny squad from Faenza, which grew out of the ashes of Minardi, and Sebastien Bourdais' fourth place proves it's no fluke. With Felipe Massa in sixth position, Raikkonen in 14th and Hamilton in 15th, it's near impossible to guess at what this race - which looks likely to start in the wet - might deliver. Coming just seven days after the Belgian grand prix (when we learned not to take anything for granted, even the result at the flag) we have the promise of a race filled with intrigue.

This is how they'll line up:
1 Sebastian Vettel (Germany) Toro Rosso-Ferrari
2 Heikki Kovalainen (Finland) McLaren
3 Mark Webber (Australia) RedBull-Renault
4 Sebastien Bourdais (France) Toro Rosso-Ferrari
5 Nico Rosberg (Germany) Williams-Toyota
6 Felipe Massa (Brazil) Ferrari

8 Fernando Alonso (Spain) Renault
9 Timo Glock (Germany) Toyota
10 Nick Heidfeld (Germany) BMW Sauber
11 Robert Kubica (Poland) BMW Sauber
12 Giancarlo Fisichella (Italy) Force India–Ferrari
13 David Coulthard (Britain) RedBull-Renault
14 Kimi Raikkonen (Finland) Ferrari

16 Rubens Barrichello (Brazil) Honda
17 Nelson Piquet (Brazil) Renault

20 Adrian Sutil (Germany) Force India-Ferrari

Predictions: Hamilton might have gone to bed after the Belgian grand prix wishing that the stewards had decided on a ten-place grid penalty at the next race rather than lopping 25 seconds off his time at the flag and taking away his win. But, in the end, he's starting this Italian grand prix from so far down the grid it feels like he has suffered both. The team has only itself to blame for today's starting position, however, as the gamble to try his first lap in Q2 on intermediate tyres was a huge error. What can he do from 15th? We need to see if he can survive the first-lap melee from the middle of the pack intact and then decide.
Up at the front, I wouldn't rule Vettel out of a podium finish. Kovalainen, from second, is odds-on for claiming his second win, but the German Toro Rosso driver starting from pole has guts and skill. Opportunities like this don't come along too often – as third-placed Mark Webber knows, too – and he'll be looking to make the most of it. Massa has had an engine change (using up his 'joker' card and thus receiving no penalty) and the team seems committed to capitalising on this race as the chance to get him into the lead of the drivers' title.
My tip for the top three is Kovalainen, Vettel and Massa. What do you all think?

David Coulthard, being interviewed on the grid, has said he thinks the race should start behind the safety car. Noooooooooo! Yes, it does look very wet, but safety car starts are about as fun as a wasp lodged in your Cornetto.

Booooo! A safety car start has been confirmed, in the interests of visibility. Let's hope they keep it short and sweet. Bernie Ecclestone told ITV F1's Martin Brundle that this is the first occasion that he's wanted the man on pole to win. Mr E has a heart!

A shock prediction from Gary Naylor - Lewis Hamilton to win! Here's his rationale: 'In the rain, one expects the best racer on the track to win. Whenever driver skill come to the fore, Hamilton shows every sign of being the heir to Senna, so, if he can be patient and avoid getting hit, I'm taking him to win.' From 15th on the grid! Yeeesss, one... and five...

Disaster for Bourdais... he doesn't appear to have got his car away from the grid for the formation lap. He'll be starting from the back, if the team can get the car going that is.

Start: So the race is underway - but behind the safety car. The only action is of the Toro Rosso mechanics trying to bring Bourdais' car back to life. It's a massive disappointment for the Frenchman, who put in a fantastic qualifying performance to line-up in fourth as he fights to keep his seat for next year.

Lap two: Away they go, Vettel leads and there's huge amounts of spray. Everyone is taking it easy. The top three positions are the same.

Lap three: Glock has passed Alonso for seventh and that seems to be one of the only overtaking moves. The TV screen is just a cloud of spray - imagine what it's like in the cockpits. Raikkonen and Hamilton are in 13th and 14th having been unable to move further up in these conditions.

Lap four: Glock cut a chicane while battling with Alonso... and Hamilton has similarly taken a shortcut further back down the field. He'll be extra cautious about it in this race...

Lap five: Raikkonen and Hamilton are now in 12th and 13th. At the front of the pack, Vettel's lead is 5 seconds and Massa is in fifth place. Bourdais is running.

Lap six: Raikkonen is only three tenths of a second behind Fisichella. It shouldn't be long before he gets the Force India car. It doesn't look like the rain is easing. Glock has had a spin in what is so far a ragged outing for the Toyota driver.

Lap eight: Hamilton looked to go inside Raikkonen - holed up behind Fisichella - at the Lesmos but he doesn't manage to get past.

Lap nine: Vettel has set the fastest race lap and Raikkonen has found a way past Fisichella at the first chicane. Hamilton needs to get past the Force India too, so that he can stay with Raikkonen.

Lap 10: Hamilton has got past Fisichella, but he didn't find it as clean and easy as Raikkonen did. He out-dragged him down the pit straight and clung on at the first corner.

Lap 11: Vettel is holding his own at the front. Hamilton has passed Raikkonen for 11th place at the first Lesmo. Looks like he's finally got the feel of his McLaren in the wet here now.

Lap 12: Massa, in fifth, is hustling Rosberg. It's a fantastic run so far from the Williams man. Some of the drivers seem to be looking for wet parts of the track as the racing line begins to dry out slightly.

Lap 14: Hamilton has passed Heidfeld for 10th place and Massa had passed Rosberg... and then let him by again... and then re-taken the place. It's all to do with chicane-cutting. And we know what the stewards think of that. Fisichella is the race's first retirement, parked up with his nose in the tyre wall.

Lap 16: Hamilton takes Glock at the first corner and then squeezes the Toyota onto the grass. The McLaren man is on a hell of a charge, now in ninth and making his intentions known to Kubica.

Lap 17: Massa set the fastest lap of the race the last time around, but Vettel's lead at the head of the field is now over 10 seconds. Kovalainen, in second, is 15 seconds ahead of Massa. Raikkonen cannot match Hamilton's pace, and he's stuck down in 12th. Teams are telling their drivers that more heavy rain is to come.

Lap 18: Vettel has pitted from the lead and they have fitted another set of extreme wet tyres.

Lap 19: At the first chicane, Hamilton has passed Alonso for seventh position. I would say he's on fire, but that might give you the wrong impression.

Lap 20: After his pitstop, Vettel is now fourth. Kovalainen leads from Webber and Massa, with all three yet to make their first stops. Raikkonen is in 12th place behind Heidfeld... where has his pace gone?

Lap 21: Alonso has dropped another place, to Glock. We've certainly seen plenty of overtaking in this race. Now Hamilton is all over the back of Trulli.

Lap 22: Careful now... Hamilton cuts a chicane while passing Trulli. He gives the place back. Now he'll have to do it all over again. The McLaren pitstop crew are out and Kovalainen pits.

Lap 23: Massa and Webber have pitted and so Vettel leads the grand prix once again. The Toro Rosso driver has a genuine chance of winning this race. Hamilton has passed Trulli now.

Do we have any Toro Rosso fans out there? What Italian-themed celebrations will you be performing if Vettel pulls this off? I've got a soft spot for the tiny outfit, and shared a pizza at their local trattoria with some of the team earlier in the year. I might re-create our fab strawberries and ricotta pudding tonight if they get this victory.

Lap 25: Hamilton has passed Rosberg (at the first chicane - where else?) and is now in second place, although he has not taken a pitstop yet.

Lap 26: Massa has found himself behind Heidfeld, who is yet to stop, and is losing time. It's not a good situation for the Ferrari driver to be in as he bids to usurp Hamilton in the drivers' championship.

Lap 27: Raikkonen has pitted but he's been nowhere so far in this race and is outside the top 10.

Lap 28: Hamilton has pitted, a smooth stop, and he rejoins in a lovely clear patch of track in 10th place.

Lap 29: Rosberg finally pits for the first time, but the team have a sticky time removing the fuel hose.

Lap 30: Coulthard has just pitted and gone out on the standard wet tyres... everyone will be watching to see how he does. The rain that the teams were predicting has not materialised yet. Ooops, he's not having much joy on them, he's gone straight on at the first chicane. Bourdais makes his first stop - from last place - what disappointment for him.

Lap 31: Alonso has finally made his first stop and he too opts for the intermediate tyres. Raikkonen has managed to overtake somebody... Trulli, for tenth place.

Lap 32: Vettel leads from Kovalainen and Kubica (who has yet to stop). Webber is in fourth place ahead of Massa and Hamilton. The McLaren man is a full ten seconds behind his Ferrari rival.

Lap 34: Massa has made another pitstop, his second, and he's gone back out on intermediate tyres. If it stays dry then his team have made the right call and the runners on full wets are going to lose out. Then again, if it rains...

Lap 35: Kovalainen, Kubica and Webber have all pitted and switched to intermediate tyres.

Lap 36: Massa is all over the back of Webber and he takes him oh-so-easily. Then Webber spins right around, but the concrete run-off saves him. Raikkonen pits.

Lap 37: Vettel pits from the lead and takes on the intermediates. Hamilton pits and switches to the same tyres. He comes out behind Webber, but takes him at the second chicane. On the edge.

Lap 39: Everyone must be watching the footie today. Apart from Mr Naylor, the only email I've had is from NatWest asking me to confirm my account details. And I don't bank with them. Vettel still heads the field after his second stop, ten seconds ahead of Kovalainen.

Lap 40: Heidfeld and Massa are squabbling over fifth position. Massa is pushing too hard - he's had a wobble and cut the chicane - and Hamilton is behind waiting to gobble him up.

Lap 41: The order is Vettel, Kovalainen, Kubica, Alonso, Heidfeld, Massa, Hamilton and Webber in the points with 12 laps to go. Will the tifosi be cheering for Italy's other team?

Lap 43: Raikkonen takes 13th from Nakajima. An awful race for the Finn, who has just signed a new contract with Ferrari. Given Hamilton's performance from one place further back on the grid, he needs to prepare his excuses.

If you're wondering what's going on in the Stoke v Everton match then check out Barney Ronay's minute-by-minute here. I won't spoil it by telling you who's winning.

Lap 45: Vettel sets his fastest time of the race, but the quickest lap of anyone belongs to Raikkonen. Not that it's going to make any difference to his race. Piquet has a big moment and Hamilton appears to have dropped his pace slightly.

Lap 47: Jenson Button (remember him?) pits. Nigel Wilson says he has RSI from hitting F5 and wants to know who's going to win. I'm thrilled to say that it's most likely going to be Sebastian Vettel, which will make him the youngest-ever grand prix winner and will restore some of the faith people may have lost in the sport after Spa. Underdogs can triumph sometimes...

Lap 48: Webber is all over Hamilton and Raikkonen is up to tenth position having passed DC. There could be some changes for position yet... In fact Raikkonen has now taken ninth from Piquet.

Lap 49: Webber and Hamilton's battle is a furious one and the pair appear to touch. Chris English think my email from NatWest was a chat-up line... more like a low-down, nasty scam to extract my pennies.

Lap 51: DC tips Nakajima into spin, or was the Williams driver at fault?

Lap 52: Vettel's lead over Kovalainen is just under 14 seconds. Come on my son!

Final lap: ... he's going to do it...

Flag: Woweee! He has done it. Sebastian Vettel - grand prix racing's new super-duper-star has won at Monza for formula one's smallest team. Kovalainen finishes second ahead of Kubica, Alonso, Heidfeld, Massa, Hamilton and Webber in the points.

Incredible. Vettel takes the flag 12 seconds ahead of Kovalainen's McLaren. It is a fantastic result for the team, the driver and the sport. And you can't say he didn't deserve it or that he won by luck.

What it means: first of all, formula one has a new youngest-ever winner. Secondly, Toro Rosso has scored its first-ever grand prix victory. Thirdly, they've embarassed their older-brother Red Bull. Fourthly... you get the point. An extraordinary performance for Vettel, but McLaren will be wondering why it couldn't propel Kovalainen onto the top step. Kubica's superior one-stop strategy will help keep him in the title hunt. Hamilton's solid drive from 15th to seventh means he retains his lead over Massa in the drivers' title battle... but only by a point. Raikkonen is out of the points and his chances of retaining his crown shrink further.

Well, I need a sit down and a cup of tea after all that excitement. Join us in a fortnight, September 28, for formula one's first-ever night race at Singapore.

The declining months of the George W Bush presidency are becoming a long fugue of fear and suspicion: fear of enemies real and imagined, and suspicion freely given and taken between key regional allies, Pakistan, Israel, Turkey and the UK among them. The knack of annoying close allies is becoming one of the few consistent features of the fag end of this presidency. The latest ally, once deemed vital to the GWB "war on terror", to be thoroughly alienated by Washington's unilateralism is Pakistan.
Authorising covert cross-border raids by US special forces from Afghanistan into Pakistan, without informing the military and political command there, may seem like tactical boldness on the part of the American president. The US commanders say that they cannot trust the Pakistan military and the Inter Service Intelligence (ISI) agency. In the past, say the Americans, local Pakistan army and ISI officers have given warnings to Taliban leaders that the Americans on search and destroy raids on alleged Taliban and al-Qaida sanctuaries.
On September 3 a team of US Navy Seals was dropped by helicopter in the area of Angoor Adda in South Waziristan, believed to be home turf of a senior Taliban, Jalalaluddibn Haqqani. It was followed by an air strike which killed two of Haqqani's wives, and some of his grandchildren. The Pakistan military said four young Taliban recruits had been killed and more than a dozen "civilians", women and children among them.
The raids were the first by US Special Operations Command since Bush signed a secret operational order in July authorising cross-border raids into Pakistan without prior notification to the authorities there. Interestingly, the first raid took place just as Asif Ali Zardari was about to be elected Pakistan's first civilian president for nine years.
Whatever the tactical gains the American commanders think they are getting from such methods, they are likely to be outweighed by the strategic crassness of these escapades. Under current international law, they could be conceived as acts of aggression and a violation of the UN Charter. At a practical level, they stand to be a powerful recruiting sergeant for the Taliban – and the millions of hitherto uncommitted Afghan refugees in Pakistan. The Pakistan army chief, General Ashfaq Parvez Kayani, said there had been, now could there be, any secret agreement to allow US covert operations in northern Pakistan. He told US forces to keep out, and said the new civilian government needed "to keep its distance" from Washington. A regional divisional commander said his forces would oppose the Americans.
On the northern side of the Pakistan border, one must wonder how much the Americans informed their other allies about precisely what they're up to in their secret ops. Not much, if American attitudes to their European Nato allies elsewhere, Britain included, are anything to go by. Contempt for the British is overt following what the Americans believe is the British defeat by Shiite militias in Basra. Their narrative now is that it took the Americans, plus nearly 30,000 troops of the Iraqi army, to restore order to the streets of Basra this spring, where the militias had been running amok. To a certain extent, it is true that the Iraqi army, plus the Americans, plus belatedly some British forces, have got the militias off the streets in Iraq's southern oil capital through their Charge of the Knights offensive. But last year, when the British troops were bearing the brunt of the Shiite attacks, the Iraqi army was neither willing nor able to tackle the militias.
The triumphalist line of the Americans and the Iraqis having the skill and will to defeat finally the Mahdi army of Moqtada al-Sadr is already coming apart at the seams. A British intelligence analyst said this week, "to claim the Sadrists have been smashed is nonsense. They are still a force." Worse, she said, the operation had driven Moqtada al-Sadr into the arms of Ayatollah Khamenei, the supreme leader of Iran. Hitherto, he had avoided getting too close to the regime in Teheran, in his aim to guarantee the independence of Iraq, and the Shiite community within it, from Iran. Once more, there are mutterings about the CIA mounting an operation to "take out" Sadr. It isn't only the Brits and the Pakistanis who fear that the American regime is misplaying, or overplaying, its hand. Two days before President Mikheil Saakashvili of Georgia ordered his troops onto the offensive in South Ossetia on August 7, the Israeli military advisory team to the Georgians quit Tbilisi. Israel has since suspended military assistance to Georgia, where it been involved in modernising the forces in partnership with the US military mission.
The most prominent Nato ally in the region, and the only one with a border with Georgia, Turkey, has appeared anxious, too, to distance itself from Washington. It has not been involved in the charge to press for Georgia and Ukraine to become members of Nato. Nor do many European Nato members want this to happen – not least because opinion polls suggest that the majority of the population in Ukraine don't want to join Nato. Meanwhile, the candidates in the US presidential race seem to be finding it hard to get their heads round the reduced circumstances of America's strategic place in the world compared with eight years ago, let alone tackle the growing divergence between the US and Europe, old and new. When Obama suggested on the stump that American forces might have to raid into Afghanistan unannounced, he was howled down. When asked in her ABC interview about the problems of border operations against Taliban/al-Qaida bases, Governor Sarah Palin seemed at a loss.
This week, both the senior US commanders involved in Iraq and Afghan operations, Admiral Mike Mullen and General David Petraeus, have warned that the coalition is not winning in Afghanistan. Far from a winning tactic, they may find that their new plan of covert raids is a short route to self-defeat.
